answers.ans_pwid_share: You might have been exposed to HIV and hepatitis through shared injecting equipment; you should get tested. Remember that injecting or using drugs exposes your health to other risks and harms. If you would like to stop using drugs but cannot make it on your own, it is important that you seek help. You can also seek advice and learn about harm reduction strategies, in order to reduce as much as possible the risks associated to drug use. Consider asking your medical doctor for a Hepatitis A & B vaccination (You will need a test before getting vaccinated

Remember that injecting or using drugs exposes your health to other risks and harms. If you would like to stop using drugs but cannot make it on your own, it is important that you seek help. You can also seek advice and learn about harm reduction strategies, in order to reduce as much as possible the risks associated to drug use. Consider asking your medical doctor for a Hepatitis A & B vaccination (You will need a test before getting vaccinated.

If you would like to stop using drugs but cannot make it on your own, it is important that you seek help. You can also seek advice and learn about harm reduction strategies, in order to reduce as much as possible, the risks associated to drug use. Consider asking your medical doctor for a Hepatitis A & B vaccination (You will need a test before getting vaccinated.

answers.ans_migrant: Screening for hepatitis B & C is recommended if you come from Central Asia; Asia; Sub-Saharan Africa; Middle-East; Central and South America where the virus is highly prevalent.
answers.ans_notbscreening: Tuberculosis is highly prevalent in Eastern Europe, Sub-Saharan Africa or Asia – so if you originate from these regions it is recommended to consult a medical doctor for TB screening.
answers.ans_tatoos: Remember that you risk getting hepatitis B, hepatitis C and/or HIV [remove if HIV+] through unsafe tattooing and piercing practices or through sharing other sharp objects with other people.
answers.ans1:
Be aware that oral sex is considered extremely low risk because saliva doesn’t transmit HIV. However, if you have any fresh cuts or sores in your mouth, infected semen, blood or vaginal fluids can enter your bloodstream when you lick or suck a penis, vagina or anus. 
Remember, what is low risk for HIV is not necessarily low risk for STIs such as syphilis, chlamydia, gonorrhoea and LGV; so, getting tested is still important if you are having any kind of sex. Other sexual acts such as fisting and sharing sex toys without cleaning them afterwards can also expose you to hepatitis and STIs. It is recommended to get tested at least twice per year or more often if you have sex often and with different partners.
answers.ans2:
Condoms when used always and correctly are very effective at preventing HIV and reducing a risk of STI. Take the Condom Test to help you choose the right condom for you.
Other sexual acts such as fisting and sharing sex toys without cleaning them afterwards can also expose you to hepatitis and STIs. It is recommended to get tested at least twice per year or more often if you have sex often and with different partners.
answers.ans3: Even though you are not worried about the risk of HIV, having sex without a condom might expose you to hepatitis and other STIs. You should get tested for hepatitis and STIs.
answers.ans4: Undetectable = Untransmittable means you cannot pass on HIV when having sex if your and/or your partner’s HIV virus is undetectable, so you are protected from HIV but not from getting hepatitis or other STIs. Remember to test regularly for other STIs, including hepatitis A, B & C.
answers.ans5: You might have been exposed to HIV and possibly hepatitis and other STIs. A full screening, which includes testing for HIV, hepatitis and STIs is recommended.
answers.ans6: PrEP protects you from HIV when having sex but not from hepatitis and other STIs; remember to get tested regularly for hepatitis and STIs.
answers.ans7: You might have been exposed to HIV, hepatitis and other STIs; you should get tested. You might have been exposed to HIV and also to hepatitis and other STIs; You should get a full screening, which includes testing for HIV, hepatitis and STIs and start taking PrEP to protect yourself from getting infected with HIV via sex.
answers.ans8: Be aware that not all sexual activities imply a risk of getting infected. You can have fun – and have kinky sex – with no risk of getting HIV, hepatitis and/or other STIs. There are many sexual activities that do not involve any risk of semen, vaginal fluids, or blood entering your blood stream: kissing – including deep or open-mouthed kissing – hugging, massaging, fondling, touching, rubbing, masturbating (alone or with your partner) are totally safe. However, other sexual acts such as fisting and sharing sex toys without cleaning them can expose you to hepatitis and STIs.
